content:
```bibtex
@article{10.1104/pp.16.00049,
    author = {Kadouche, Derifa and Ducatez, Mathieu and Cenci, Ugo and Tirtiaux, Catherine and Suzuki, Eiji and Nakamura, Yasunori and Putaux, Jean-Luc and Durand Terrasson, Amandine and Diaz-Troya, Sandra and Florencio, Francisco Javier and Arias, Maria Cecilia and Striebeck, Alexander and Palcic, Monica and Ball, Steven G and Colleoni, Christophe},
    title = {Characterization of Function of the GlgA2 Glycogen/Starch Synthase in Cyanobacterium sp. Clg1 Highlights Convergent Evolution of Glycogen Metabolism into Starch Granule Aggregation},
    journal = {Plant Physiology},
    volume = {171},
    number = {3},
    pages = {1879--1892},
    year = {2016},
    month = {05},
    doi = {10.1104/pp.16.00049},
    pmcid = {PMC4936547},
    pmid = {27208262},
    abstract = {At variance with the starch-accumulating plants and most of the glycogen-accumulating cyanobacteria, Cyanobacterium sp. CLg1 synthesizes both glycogen and starch. We now report the selection of a starchless mutant of this cyanobacterium that retains wild-type amounts of glycogen. Unlike other mutants of this type found in plants and cyanobacteria, this mutant proved to be selectively defective for one of the two types of glycogen/starch synthase: GlgA2. This enzyme is phylogenetically related to the previously reported SSIII/SSIV starch synthase that is thought to be involved in starch granule seeding in plants. This suggests that, in addition to the selective polysaccharide debranching demonstrated to be responsible for starch rather than glycogen synthesis, the nature and properties of the elongation enzyme define a novel determinant of starch versus glycogen accumulation.},
    url = {https://doi.org/10.1104/pp.16.00049}
}
```
